threads.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a corncob pipe and a pouch of either Captain Black or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).

Having trouble keeping your pipe lit? Fill it with less tobacco and smoke it slower than you think you need to, lightly tamping as needed when the smoke starts thinning out.

threads.com:
Hello Out

I want to go on a long and extended walk/hike/trek in Scotland where wild camping is legal so I can relax for an extended period of time without slipping into decadence like people do at holiday resorts and have nothing to do but walk and read. I plan to do this summer 2023 after my A levels and before university. By then I will have at least £1000 in savings and probably more (I now have about £900). Will this be feasible.

£1.70 for a weeks worth of rice
£0.60 for a weeks worth of carrots
£5 for two lamb chops
£3 for a roll of proper bread (normal supermarket bread in the uk is actually a bread substitute but if you’re willing to pay extra you can get actual bread quite easily).

I should note that I’m an autist so I won’t mind eating mostly rice with other food in smaller amounts to get necessary nutrients and would probably prefer it over variation as I like routine.

I imagine I could roast vegetables easily in a mess tin (German/polish/Russian variety) and make a decent if oddly shaped Yorkshire pudding in the removable dish that comes with the mess kit.

Shelter: bothies. Carry a zeltbhan in case I can’t find a bothy.

Entertainment: the natural world+books. I will buy books to read on the trip and then pass them on or something when I’m done with them.

Clothes:
I’ll bring 2 pairs of trousers and 3/4 cotton or linen shirts. I’ll also bring a jumper or two. Will be packed in a rucksack.

I also want to do this to prove to my friends that cost of living is low outside of rent and vices
but that is an afterthought that came to me whilst typing this post. My main motivation is a sense of wanderlust and desire for solitude to think and to read.

Misc:
Needles+thread
Lighter
Swiss army knife
Water bottle
Might bring an axe
Torch

Anything I’ve missed? Is this feasible?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505114
Thanks
>Headlamp
Already got one
>Food
I assume you’re an American. England normally has a supermarket in every village. Lowland Scotland is much the same. We don’t really get “food deserts” like in America. I might use salt to preserve meats. Rice can easily just be kept in the bag it comes in (the bags are 1kg and this should last me about a week). I’ve cooked steak over a disposable BBQ whilst camping before and imagine it will be much the same cooking other meats. Might need oil to grease the mess kit pan but otherwise I think I’ll be fine. Plan on using something like pic rel. Is there any real difference between nations of origin or are they all basically the same?
>maps
Okay here’s the part where living in modern Britain is actually cool. The entire country is mapped in detail by the Ordinance Survey and civilians are allowed to by OS maps that are extremely detailed down to showing farmer’s sheds. I will probably be able to buy OS maps as I walk along. Already own a map case.
>water
Water is cheap in uk and rainwater tastes okay. If I need to I can just buy water. Often place will give out free water. Eg at train stations.

The issue with food and water is its weight. Thats why people bring filters and fill up at streams rather than carrying what they need. The latter might be feasible though, depending on how developed the area is. You don’t want to carry several days worth of water (for drinking and cooking).

Maps are the same in the US, done by the US Geological Survey. You can probably get free digital copy’s of OS maps that are geospatial referenced. That is, the digital copy has GPS data connected to the image, so when it’s viewed on a GPS-capable device it shows your location. It makes a really handy backup and a quick way to defense your location. I think Europe uses Galileo instead of GPS, but I wouldn’t be surprised if the files worked with GPS, Galileo, and GLONASS.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Why do people like kukris so much?
threads.com: I bought myself a kukri a year or so ago, used it extensively as a camp duty tool. It really seems like a neat idea in theory but in practice it just doesn't work for me no matter how hard I try. It's too cumbersome to be a good replacement for a knife, it's too light to be a good replacement for a hatchet. It's also a pain in the ass to take care of due to the fact that it has a recurve shape. The only scenario where it's actually reasonable to use it is clearing slightly thick branches or really thick weeds where a regular machete doesn't have enough weight to cut through. I can't count how many times I found myself wishing I packed proper tools instead. Why are people so obsessed about these things? Have I fallen for a meme?

I never said it's the most versatile instrument. What I said is that it's a lot of bang for the buck (where the currency is size - the smaller the better). You get two full octaves of a major scale, with (a useful) bit of a third on the bottom. You get a minor scale and all the modes in between. There's hundreds of tunes you can play with just this. And there's lots of room for expression: wide dynamic range, chords (limited, but they're there, and they are useful in typical for-harmonica tunes), bends. Name a different literally pocket sized instrument that's this versatile.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503222
Sailing (as in, letting the wind propel you) is not hard to learn. If all you had was wind, and flat water all around you, it wouldn't be hard to "sail".

But it's not like that. You have islands, underwater rocks, buoys, other boats, rules, currents, wind drift, weather, and you can't stay at sea forever. A boat never "stops", you can't hit the brakes like with a car. It's all real-time. Navigating, maneuvering in ports, mooring... that's harder.

last_replies.com:
West Coast Trail on Vancouver Island is a good 5-6 day haul, unfettered beaches, old shipwreck rubbish, crashing waves with nothing but ocean between you and Japan, waterfalls and ladders, self-propelled cable gondolas over clear rivers, humpback whales and bald eagles, lush PNW forests...a little tent restaurant in the middle of the trail with $25 burgers, Washington State visible across the Juan de Fuca Strait going south..but as usual on the Island, there can be relentless rain and ankle-deep mud, with a full pack you may only clear 10 kilometers on an inclement day.

Definitely something to consider.

threads.sub: Beginner Gear General - Poor Fag Edition
threads.com:
I wanted to make a thread for General new gear and where to get it. Also for Larpers and Woodsman alike to avoid the pit falls I fell into when choosing gear for the first time over 2 years ago. i'll try to aim for a good gear loadout under 200$. Also any criticisms or better options should be talked about here.

Ill first go by stating the things no anon should ever cheap out on.
>boots
you should aim for boots over 200$ price range eventually, but if you are just getting started buy military surplus boots. But If you can avoid do not buy the recent desert tan army boots that run 20$. They have very thick soles and no ankle support , its a good way to give yourself a sprang ankle, they are also not very breathable or water proof. But I used them for a year so they are workable but do have a week or 2 brake in period.

Next is backpacks I see many on here choose a military surplus backpack, My experience with a US military molle 2 rucksack is that its usable at best but too heavy. Military sacrifices price and quality material for an indestructible pack that an idiot can't destroy. You are better off with a used frame backpack or internal backpack.

I have found that most milltary backpacks are around 65-120$ a used backpacking bag is around 20$ on shopgoodwill.com. I hear you say that you don't want to stand out in the woods , I would say their are plenty of waterproof rain flys for your bag that come in non-IRreflective camo for 45$ or a Chinese rain fly for 10$ on amazon, which are better than what ever camo you were thinking about buying any how. A good capacity is 65 liters, this is considered 3 day bag but if your smart you can fit rations for a full week in it. 55 liters is fine but the limit for fitting a sleeping bag and not limiting the gear you might want to take. Finally you need to have a waist support for your backpack as well as a frame , this should go without saying a duffel bag is a pain to hull around 5 miles.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504286
I don't know what the most normal route order is, but the most challenging is from Trollheimshytta to Gjevilvasshytta in that order. So you definitely want to do it the other way around for the most pleasant and scenic route (beautiful views when walking in the Gråsjøen direction to Trollheimshytta from Gjevilvasshytta as starting point) They've also added (to my distaste) a bridge over the first major river there so if there's a lot of water when you go you will save yourself from that by walking over the bridge. From there you can either go through the valley which leads to Jøldalshytta which is a very simple hike, or take the more challenging one up the mountain, which in return gives you way better views. The last part of the trip from Jøldalshytta to Gjevilvasshytta is unknown to me, but from what I've gathered it's a reasonably simple hike, with bridges over the two main rivers there. The cabins are own by Den Norske Turistforening (DNT) so you will find out everything you need to know about the cabins from them. I never use cabins (except when I was on norways tallest mountain) so idk much about them. Have eaten a kanelbolle at gjevilvasshytta though, good shit. During the main season for hiking in Norway there's a lot of people doing trekanten, but the cabins are only open for a limited time during the summer, so you can't really get a trip alone unless you head out during autumn. It costs 70kr to drive in to the valley using some app, and it costs to park by Gjevilvasshytta. If you park by the beach (Rauøra) it's completely free, but it can be really busy,

last_replies.com: Hell yeah. One of the most fun part of motorcycling is the ease of camping. This is me after firing the bike into a park that was closed for the season via the pedestrian footpath, and I decided to bring luxury as I was staying for 3 days and brought a tent. Normally, I sleep under my cover - I bought a dark green ATV cover for the cruiser, as it has enough space underneath it to cover the bike fully while also allowing me to ground sleep underneath it. This time, I wanted some comforts, and turns out a 6 man tent will fit a decent wheelbase machine nicely. Did a few wrapped in a greatcoat under that cover while the night temperature hut freezing, which was amusing waking up with frost on the cover to then go riding down the same roads. I always have that green cover and a flat-packable woodstove in my saddlebag, just in case I feel like getting silly. Dirtbag camping is a riot!

Only multitool I need. Leatherman wave.
Got it as a gift ages ago and really love it as a good alrounder. You have quick access to the cutting tools and it has stuff you can at least get some use out of, rather than 50 features I do neither want nor need. It's built like a tank and has withstood some insane abuse by me, including leaving it outside for over a year in a bowl that collected rain and snow. All I got was this matte patina, it still works perfectly.
It's very expensive, but you notice the quality your money gets you at least and for me due to the memories I made with it and it being a gift by my parents I have become emotionally attached to it at this point.
>tell me why you think it's the perfect one for you
Has all the features I regularly use, but not many more. Sturdy, doesn't get damaged easily, good form factor, gets the job done for basically any task, be it cutting wire, holding things, pulling thorns out of my skin, cracking nuts, cutting things, or anything related. Pair it with a extra knife for fishing that is easy to clean and you got 80% of usecases covered and can probably improvise something with it for the other 20%.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503525
>Is there any danger in being so close to the antennas?
The 2way/LMR stuff isn't too bad. 100 watts or so with a couple dB antenna gain on it. Unless you're really close to it or working on the specific antenna when it's still lit up, there's not much of an exposure hazard. Those duty-cycle too, they're only on when someone's using the talk path, so overall exposure is reduced because of the time factor.
Dishes or directional antennas focus that energy in one direction; while they usually have less power into them, all that power is directed one way. Don't stand or work in front of those.
Broadcast transmitters are the scary ones. Lots of power, 100% duty cycle, and they're usually in bands that the body absorbs easily.
The tower in >picrel is AM broadcast, the tower structure is the antenna and it's electrically hot. Knocked power down while we were on it, less for exposure and more to minimize the risk of RF burns in case of accidental contact with the grounded cables I was installing. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b9UO9tn4MpI
On top of that tower was a 10-element FM broadcast array with about 50kW out of it.
When I climbed up to set an anchor the day before the install, knowing the two of us were only going to be up there for a short time, we didn't mess with the FM power levels. My alarm got real alarmy up there because of that exposure. The next day during the install, I coordinated with station engineer to ramp down power on that transmitter to acceptable levels while I was working ~15ft below that array.

Part of my pre-climb safety assessment includes RF exposure considerations.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I want to go walking in Norway for a month or two between May and August next year, ideally somewhere in the far north around Tromso og Finnmark.
I don't want to stick to paths but I don't want to be wading through should height bogs, not sure if those are a problem outside of the UK.
My experience in Scandinavia is limited to Lillehammer and Svalbard in summer and general experience will just be walking around the UK.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
May is too early. Mid to end of June has a lot of mosquitos right after the snowmelt. July and August will be best. If you like autumn and can handle the weather and a bit of snow September is very nice as well.

No need to stick to trails above the treeline but you will get bogs everywhere even on marked trails. How deep they are depends on how much it has been raining.

The most scenic route is the Nordkalottleden. You can hike the northern section in two to three weeks or otherwise build your trail around it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502904
Would May be too early because of the snow? July and August would be good as I could work a few more months before coming, will it get busy around that time?
Also, do you know the names of the company that runs those huts around Norway? They had a key to get into them and cost around 300 krona, not sure if they're still around

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: DNT there are also still many open huts this far north but you have to find them. They are usually not directly on the trail. End of June to mid August is tourist season. A lot of people for my taste. General hiking season is from mid June to mid September.

threads.name: backpacks
threads.com:
I'm stuck tossing up between getting a backpack in the style of picrel with MOLLE, or a normal Osprey kind of one.
I guess I think that an Osprey would be the more practical option, being lighter and probably more comfortable. On the other hand, having pouches and stuff attached to my bag is fun, I like the look, and in general I am not opposed to a bit of LARPing. I like the Highlander forces one in the pic but I can only get it in black in Australia, which will get too hot. Anyone know any other good brands?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: and also if this is your first/primary backpack, i agree with you op 40-45 liters is the right size for most people for this. the one specific thing to look for is a pack that cinches down to smaller sizes well and carries well when it does. that way you can use this same backpack for your day-hikes and also your shorter backpacking trips, instead of needing two separate packs. not all backpacks 'scale down' well. picrel is an example of a good design.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: the other thing to look for when buying is the torso length of the pack. have a friend measure your torso for you. when anon and i say basically any pack will work for you, its with the caveat: has to fit well. if you're looking at either cheap or lightweight packs they're often not very adjustable so make sure to get it right. watch a few videos on youtube about how to fit a pack & bring a simulated load to fill it up with if you have the luxury of buying your backpack in person at a store.
